title: Wednesday, 2nd November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hello, welcome, hi there, hey.

BE

And don't panic.

BE

Everything's going to be fine. We've dispatched Paul to America to sort out their mess.

11:03 am
BE

He'll be in NYC for the remainder of the week, and therefore won't be joining us here.

BE

By "mess" I mean this, of course.

BE

11:04 am
BE

Can a person with a complete lack of scruples, an obvious contempt for his own supporters and an indeterminable amount of money become president of the world's biggest economy?

BE

The answer is still: Maybe!

BE

That chart's from the FT's poll tracker, which is really good: https://ig.ft.com/us-elections/polls

11:05 am
BE

As is Nate Silver. But you know what already: http://fivethirtye..._cid=story-twitter

undefined
BE

Markets responding calmly to the potential death of western democracy.

11:06 am
BE

FTSE down 0.3% at pixel, off 18 points.

BE

(@Otter: yes, though with Nate the headline prediction's always the least important bit.)

BE

GB Krona buys $1.228ish, up 0.3% on my screen.

11:08 am
BE

Oil down 1.6%ish.

BE

And results .......... everywhere is results.

BE

Should we start with Wetherspoon? I feel we must.

11:09 am
J D Wetherspoon PLC (JDW:LSE): Last: 833.50, down 54.5 (-6.14%), High: 866.00, Low: 829.15, Volume: 195.28k
BE

Three parts to the statement.

BE

First, we get some new material from Wetherspoon founder and chairman, Al Murray

11:10 am
BE

Sorry .... Tim Martin.

BE

Typo.

BE

Angela Merkel of Germany and François Hollande of France have supported the stance of the unelected EU 'President' Juncker in stating that the "UK must pay a price" for leaving the EU and that there "must be a threat" to the UK. According to press reports, Juncker told European business leaders, in October, not to negotiate with UK companies and to adopt an "intransigent" attitude. This suggested approach puts an unfair burden on the excellent European suppliers with which UK companies, like Wetherspoon, have traded for many decades. For example, Wetherspoon normally agrees on trade deals with suppliers for 3 to 10 years. If we, and companies like ours, are unable to agree on tariff-free transactions, it will inevitably result in a loss of business for European companies which have done nothing to deserve this outcome. Indeed, the ultimate sanction will be in the hands of UK consumers, should they take offence at the hectoring and bullying approach of Juncker and co. French wine, Champagne and spirits, German beer and Swedish cider, for example, are all at extreme risk.

11:10 am
BE

Yep -- that'll be a prominent Brexiteer whining about the uncertainty caused by losing EU trade pacts.

BE

(@Kreditkid: it's an MSM conspiracy. I'm being paid by Putin to type this.)

BE

..... And in effect calling for his customers to boycott these "excellent", "blameless" European suppliers, to protest "bullying" by "Juncker and co".:

11:11 am
BE

That's a quality bit of joined-up thinking.

BE

(Oh, and there's no capital C on champagne. A landlord should know that.)

BE

Now -- that's all such obvious noisy nonsense, it can only be a sleight of hand.

11:12 am
BE

And, yup! trading's terrible.

BE

Slower than expected LfL sales growth

BE

4% which is okay-ish, but slowing to 2.3% in the final five weeks

11:13 am
BE

Connected with an "unusually high" margin, up 280bps.

BE

Which, if I got the gist of the conference call correctly, is on higher prices.

BE

Note also the caution that the margin bump will dissipate as LFLs continue to slow.

11:14 am
BE

So while the FY outlook's unchanged, it looks to depend on a pickup that looks highly uncertain.

BE

Which leads us onto part three!

BE

"Following a recent meeting with a major shareholder ........."

11:15 am
BE

... they're having to do a massive degearing.

BE

Bear in mind this is a company that's been geared up the wazoo for its entire existence. That was its USP.

BE

Oh, and maintenance capex is nearly doubling.

11:15 am
BE

So if you were in expecting the share buyback to run long term ... sorry.

BE

0-2x net debt to EBITDA is the "a sensible long-term benchmark", against 3.5x currently.

BE

Here's Mark Brumby's notes from the relevant bit of the conference call.

11:16 am
BE

· When do you aim to get below 2x debt to EBITDA? No target date given – but this could be 5-10yrs.
· Debt this year will be ‘similar to or a little higher than last year’.
· Does this mean buy-backs are now on hold? These are ‘always opportunistic’. The group doesn’t forecast when these will take place.
· Could still spend £0-60m on shares. Might, obviously, be near the £0m. Group will still go through with the Whitewash proposal (to allow further purchases if Tim Martin goes through 30% as a result of buy-backs)
· How much spent on buy-back this year to date? Around £18m.
· Why change your leverage levels? Says ‘as the company matures, it will not need to add debt to the same levels – or possibly at all’. Group says Tim is a ‘young-61’ but when management changes, group may run on lower leverage.

BE

Oh, I dunno. Have some balance. Barclays reckons it's all great.

BE

Strong Q1 IMS: LFL sales growth of 3.5% for the 13 weeks to 23 October. This compares with LFL sales growth in the first 6 weeks of FY17 of 4.1%. This implies LFLs of 3% in the last 7 weeks (assuming equal weighting). Although this is a slowdown, it remains materially above the Coffer Peach tracker (LFLs of 1.8% for September). Comps from FY16 weren’t particularly tough for Wetherspoon by their own high standards, with LFL sales growth in Q1 FY16 of 2.4%, but these did get tougher in the latter 7 weeks of Q1 16 to 3.3%. EBIT margins in Q1 were 8.6%, materially higher than Q1 FY16 (5.8%) FY16 (6.9%), and still significantly higher than H2 16 (7.5%). We forecast margins of 6.9% for FY17. In terms of guidance, the company has this morning said they "currently anticipates an operating margin of around 7%” for FY17, close to our forecast. If margins are retained at the Q1 level, admittedly not the company’s guided scenario, and applied to our sales forecast, then the company would deliver EBIT of £139m, 25% higher than our FY17 EBIT forecast of £112m (Bloomberg consensus £112m). The 8am call will be important in understanding why the company has delivered such a strong Q1 margin performance, and why they expect it to fall for the remainder of the year. We believe that price increases in December 2015 and March 2016, as well as early increases in the wage bill have been important drivers of margin recovery. The company has opened 1 new pub in the year to date and disposed of 9. Gross openings are expected to be 15 in FY17. The shares have de-rated recently but are still up c40% from their January lows, now trading at an FY17E P/E of 16.7x, EV/EBITDA 8.2 x, FCF yield 10.7%.

11:21 am
BE

(@MCentral: you're saying there's sense to Mr Martin's argument that consumers should boycott European goods to put pressure on the EU to give the UK tariff-free trade as such an agreement would help total sales of European goods? If so, we disagree. The capitalisation of the c in champagne is no more than a footnote here.)

undefined
BE

Further to results, we have Next rallying.

11:22 am
Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 5,010, up 200 (+4.16%), High: 5,040, Low: 4,750, Volume: 733.06k
BE

Sales look pretty bad, even against lowered expectations, but full-year guidance doesn't change.

BE

This is seen as a positive against forecasts that sales would meet lowered expectations but full-year guidance would change.

11:23 am
BE

And it's full-year guidance you can drive a bus though. 5% swing.

BE

The big worry here is Directories, which seems to have stalled entirely.

BE

Raising all the old questions about whether cleaning up credit quality turns the mail-order business ex growth.

11:25 am
BE

Here's Citi .............

BE

Next has reported sales growth at the low end of conservative expectations and although sales in October were positive after significant declines in August and September the shift in momentum is not as material as some hoped. The lack of growth in Directory is also a concern. The company has narrowed guidance and marginally reduced the mid-range which is likely to cause some small downwards pressure (c.-1%) to consensus PBT on the back of today’s statement.

BE

Total sales in Retail were -5.9%, which given space contribution of +2.2%, implies Next Retail LFL -7.9% (Citi -7%). August sales (-7.0%) were impacted by the large end-of-season clearance in July, September (-5.1%) was against the toughest comp of last year while October (+1.3%) saw some growth as comparables became less challenging. There is no weekly chart.

11:25 am
BE

Next now expects Brand sales growth of -1.75% to +1.25% (from -2.5 to +2.5%) and FY17 PBT of £785-825m (from £775-845m). At the mid-point this implies FY17 PBT of £805m, c.1% below previous mid-point of £810m and but broadly in-line with current consensus of c.£800m.

BE

At top end of guidance this sales growth implies 4Q full price sales c.+7.0% or c.-2.0% at the bottom end of the range. Comparables get c.7%pts easier in 4Q vs 3Q.

BE

Consensus PBT likely to fall marginally — We would expect some small downwards pressure (c.-1%) on consensus forecasts on the back of this statement. For the record, we have a £810m Jan 2017E PBT (EPS 442.9p, +0.6% yoy). This assumes 2H17e Next Brand sales +1.9% (LFL +0.8%; split Retail -1.1% (LFL -3.0%, space +1.9%), Directory +6.2%), and 20.4% Next Brand EBIT margin (-60bps yoy).

11:26 am
BE

Our 4,800p target price is based on an 11.5x PE multiple to FY18e EPS. This target equates to a c.10x EV/EBIT multiple and 3.7% dividend yield for the same forecast year.

BE

And Investec.

BE

A challenging Q3 for Next is unsurprising given tough comps and unseasonal weather. We note performance in Home has started to trend back into line with Clothing, suggesting trading is challenging across the Next Brand. While comps ease in Q4, better-than-expected performance on FY cost savings prevents greater downgrades. We continue to remain cautious on Next given the maturity profile of its core Directory business and, while there is some valuation support given its cash generation, downward risks to forecasts remain.

Q3 (13 weeks to 29 Oct) a mixed bag: Reporting Brand full price sales -3.5% (INVe: -4.5%, consensus: -2%), with trading impacted by a poor August & September with a pick-up in October.
Retail remains under pressure with sales -5.9% (INVe: -6.5%, consensus: 6%) and implied LFL c. -8%. By month, August and September were particularly soft (-7% and -5.1% respectively) with an improvement in October (+1.3%) under more normalised conditions. We note that sales within Home have trended back towards Clothing (having outperformed in H1).
Directory performance softer than expected with sales 0.0% (INVe -1.5%, consensus: +3%). Within this, we would expect that Label and International continued to outperform (having delivered all of H1’s growth), implying core UK Brand Directory sales (75% of Directory product sales) have fallen in Q3 (INVe -3 to -4%), which in our view continues to add pressure to the direction of profitability within the Directory going forwards.
Guidance narrowed: Next is guiding to FY17 full-price sales of -1.75% to +1.25%, PBT of £785m-£825m with better cost savings delivered than expected (was -2.5% to +2.5%, £775-845m), versus INVe of £798m.
Valuation has some yield support with Next on 10.5x CY17e P/E, 3.7% dividend yield, and capable of returning c. 5% through a share buyback. However, we remain concerned over the direction of travel for group profits and margins in the face of incoming inflationary headwinds. TP lowered to 4580p, reflecting increased risks on headwinds for Next going forwards.

11:27 am
BE

Peel Hunt also.

BE

Whilst there will be few within NEXT’s head office that look
back on Q3 17 with much affection, today’s update soothed
nerves on a number of levels. In the immediate term, trading
seems to have stabilised: LFL is still negative but not in freefall,
and we believe that there is pent-up demand in the clothing
sector. These aren’t vintage times but NEXT is in good enough
form to ride that wave. What was even more interesting to us was
NEXT’s ability to mitigate the impact of lower sales growth with
cost savings: there are no changes to forecasts today. Growth
companies have the volumes to fend off external factors, and
those with less natural expansiveness will mitigate their effects
with the flexibility of cost and supplier base. NEXT is in the
latter camp. 2017 will doubtless be a tougher year for the sector,
but valuations expect much leaner returns than are likely. At
NEXT, now that trading and forecasts seem to have stabilised,
the REDUCE stance is played out and we move back to HOLD.

BE

The point to drive home here, I guess, is that while Next's numbers are pretty terrible the expectations ahead of them were even worse.

11:28 am
undefined
BE

Odey mentioned on the right.

BE

(Bloomberg) -- Crispin Odey, whose main hedge fund has lost
about 43 percent this year, says U.K. stocks could slump 80
percent as the economy is roiled by a recession and higher
inflation following the vote to leave the European Union.

11:29 am
BE

That's how you size-and-scope. Good work, Bloomberg's Nishant Kumar.

BE

And as we know, he's short of a slightly odd basket of stuff.

BE

All the supermarkets. Many of the miners. Weir, Ashtead, Burberry.

11:32 am
BE

Carillion (which was until quite recently London's most crowded short)

BE

Ocado (ditto)

BE

Just Eat, Intu, Relx .....

11:02 am
BE

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily you know thing whatever.

undefined
BE

What doesn't help his thesis is HSBC, which upgrades Easyjet this morning.

11:34 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 973.00, up 32.5 (+3.46%), High: 979.50, Low: 952.00, Volume: 2.01m
BE

..... Oh, hang on. I seem to have lost that note. We'll come back to it.

undefined
11:37 am
BE

Instead, perhaps stop in on Stan.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 643.10, down 30.2 (-4.49%), High: 661.00, Low: 637.50, Volume: 4.00m
BE

Still sliding post yesterday's pretty terrible numbers, which seem to have undermined the idea that it can take costs out and keep revenues stable.

11:39 am
BE

Berenberg has a wobble on its buy call.

BE

We are removing Standard Chartered (STAN) from the Berenberg Alpha
list as we no longer have enough upside to justify its continuing inclusion.
STAN remains Buy rated as we believe management is focused on risk and
return, and owning a USD-exposed asset in a USD scarce world is
attractive. Upside in the near term seems capped as dividends look unlikely
to be restarted and the revenue environment continues to be difficult.

BE

Risk differentiation key to long-term performance: The difficulty with
being risk-and-return-focused in a world where central banks are
suppressing risk pricing, is that there are few 10% RoE opportunities,
which puts pressure on revenues. However, this should not result in longterm
underperformance for STAN providing there is a focus on capital
return, especially where opportunities to redeploy capital are not available.
● Revenue opportunities scarcer: Our initial premise on STAN was that
revenues had been impacted in H2 2015 and Q1 2016 as management
changed scorecards for employees, ascertained what risk was on the balance
sheet and a quarter of senior staff were let go. Once these issues were
overcome we forecast revenues to grow 7% pa, but this seems unlikely to
happen considering current trends and management commentary. The
operating environment remains tough, competition has not let up and the
days of global trade growing at double GDP seem far distant.

11:40 am
BE

Costs may need to come down further: In setting out its original plan,
STAN had aimed to keep costs flat in absolute terms. STAN should easily
achieve this, mainly because the environment has been tougher than
expected. While STAN wants to see if the investment it has put into the
business generates better revenue growth, a further reappraisal of the cost
base may be needed to improve returns.
● Capital return delayed: Hope had been building that dividends could be
restarted in 2016, but this seems unlikely. Management flagged with Q3
2016 results that a number of capital headwinds remain. While we forecast
STAN to end the year with a CET1 ratio of 13.6%, above its target range of
12-13%, we see STAN erring on the side of caution. Further upside and
longer-term outperformance is likely to come once STAN restarts the
dividend and can deliver capital return.
● Returns unlikely to be more than 5%: Pulling all this together means
STAN is unlikely to generate ROEs of more than 5%, which compares to
management’s original target of 8% in 2018 with the strategic plan.

BE

And Barclays sticks by its "sell" call.

BE

Stabilised at a low level: 2016 has so far been a year of stabilisation for Standard
Chartered and management acknowledge that there’s a lot of work still to be done to
get returns back to an acceptable level. The balance sheet has been largely de-risked,
leading to fairly stable, if still high, provisions, and revenues have also leveled out after
substantial declines. Efficiency improvements are underway and provisions should
come down in time, but the company will need to generate substantial revenue growth
to come close to returns that justify its current 0.7x tangible book multiple, in our view.
We see this as the key challenge for Standard Chartered and an area where there has
been limited progress so far. We expect Standard Chartered’s underlying RoTE to
bottom out at 2% in 2016, rising to 5% next year but only reaching 7% by 2019,
assuming that income can grow 4% a year from here. Capital is a potential positive and
some of this could come back to shareholders in time but at 0.7x tangible book value
and 14.6x 2017E earnings we continue to see the shares as overvalued.

11:41 am
BE

Significant growth needed: The strategy announced a year ago indicated that cost
reduction and provision normalisation would be fully offset by strategic investments,
RWA actions and regulatory headwinds, which leaves revenues the sole driver of RoE
improvements. Stabilisation is a good start but we estimate the company would need to
deliver double-digit revenue growth in each of the next two years to get close to its
initial 8% RoE target for 2018. This target was pushed back at the time of Q2 results,
but given the tough revenue demands we expect Standard Chartered to fall a long way
short of an 8% RoE in 2018.
Provisions stable with underlying improvement: Total provisions were stable in the
quarter, down 1% QoQ to $0.8bn or 120bp of loans. The underlying trend is a little
more positive with the charge for the ongoing business falling 8% QoQ by 10bp to
101bp of loans but offset by higher provisions against the liquidation portfolio. This
should be much reduced by the end of the year with future charges much more
reflective of the ongoing business. There was some slippage in credit quality of the
ongoing business with NPLs and near-NPLs deteriorating slightly in Q3.

undefined
BE

So I promised you an Easyjet upgrade. So here's that Easyjet upgrade.

11:42 am
BE

HSBC goes from reduce to buy.

BE

It's cheap, is the gist.

BE

Ryanair and easyJet should outperform low cost peers: Next year Ryanair and
easyJet will benefit from significant fuel price improvements, in contrast to their low
cost competitors, whose fuel hedging has seen the benefit from falling market prices
sooner. Ryanair and easyJet remain the long-term strategic winners in the market
with solid strategic positions and strong balance sheets. Despite easyJet’s current
short-term commercial and operational challenges, we continue to see it as one of
the two market leaders.

easyJet strong valuation case: On our estimates, easyJet trades on a CY17 PE of 9.2x,
a 21% discount to Ryanair and an 18% discount to its own 5-year average. Thinking long
term, assessing easyJet and Ryanair on the basis of their mid cycle PBT margins of 10%
and 19% respectively, easyJet trades on 8.7x, at a 35.8% discount to Ryanair. If easyJet
management fail to turn its trading around, we would expect peers to be interested in its
strategic position, network and brand.

11:44 am
BE

Meanwhile, transatlantic competition for the flag carriers.

BE

Why do we take a more positive stance? At this time, we think the structural disequilibrium in the European short haul market is quite widely understood by investors.

This differs from what we regard as the building threat to the North Atlantic’s profits, where we think overly optimistic commentators are too keen to extrapolate the behaviour of the consolidated US airline market onto the North Atlantic. We see a swathe of peripheral carriers and low cost operators set to destabilise this market in our view. Even within the main alliances Air Canada and Aer Lingus are both building their sixth freedom connecting hubs targeting the core US Europe market.

BE

(@Mouselet: Dunno. The Easyjet bid rumour was another one of those that kicked off earlier in the year, looked convincing enough to do some serious work on, then went absolutely nowhere. We've had at least a dozen like that this year, which is new. It's as time-consuming as it has been frustrating.)

11:47 am
undefined
BE

What else then? Apologies if I've missed requests, it's always a wee bit trickier when it's a monologue on this side of the page.

BE

We do, Boncour notes, have the FOMC policy update later today.

11:51 am
BE

December rate hike still a possibility.

BE

.... Though a hike today would be proper fun, in context.

BE

Deutsche's FI team says ............

11:52 am
BE

On the eve of a heated presidential election and with market expectations of a
policy move at this meeting running very low, the FOMC is not about to raise
rates another 25 bps this week. The question is, how strong a signal will they
give for a rate hike in December? On this, DB’s Peter Hooper suggests that, a
substantial majority of the Committee has already let it be known via their
interest rate projections that they expect to raise rates by December, and many
have backed up these forecasts made in September with more recent
speeches. Unlike a year ago when the Committee clearly signaled a rate hike
at the “next meeting,” market expectations do not need to be guided higher at
this time. They already stand at near 70% on a December hike. Moreover,
because the picture remains somewhat mixed, Chair Yellen may want to keep
her options for December more open.

BE

And VTB's Neil MacKinnon, puilling all the threads together.

BE

The S&P500 index closed down 0.7% last night and Asian equity markets are
in the red this morning. In the scheme of things, this is so far a relatively
minor reaction, though clearly the risk is that a market correction intensifies.
Technical analysts will be looking to see whether nearby key support at the
200-day moving average of 2,080 holds. If not, a 10-15% correction beckons.
In this scenario, the likelihood of the FOMC hiking rates at next month’s
meeting clearly diminishes. The FOMC actually concludes its current policy
meeting later today, though it is widely expected to be a non-event. The main
focus for Fed-watchers is any change of language in the statement that
acknowledges a stronger economy (though the Fed thinks the trend growth
rate of the US economy is 1.5-1.75% a year, taking into account
demographics and slower productivity growth) or anything that points to a
stronger preference for monetary tightening.
Friday’s US jobs report is unlikely to be a game-changer. The US
unemployment rate is already close to what the Fed thinks is the ‘natural
rate’, or long-run rate. With labour force growth slowing to about 0.5% a year
due to an aging population, an increase in nonfarm payroll employment of
between 50-100k is sufficient to steady the unemployment rate.
Hence a ‘low’ jobs number might be regarded by the Fed as evidence of
diminishing slack in the labour market and, therefore, a reason to tighten
policy. Either way, the capacity of the Fed to raise rates during 2017 is
constrained by expectations that the real equilibrium rate of interest is near
zero, implying that a 2% inflation rate points to the fed funds rate rising not
much more than 2% in the current cycle.

11:55 am
BE

Oh, chartism. Sorry.

undefined
BE

Let me just hammer through the remaining stuff. Smurfit first.

11:55 am
Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 1,823, up 63 (+3.58%), High: 1,848, Low: 1,776, Volume: 736.33k
BE

Q3 beats, outlook reassuringly boring.

BE

You'll remember Smurfit failed to push through a price hike last month

11:58 am
BE

Trying to offset higher prices of old corrugated container

BE

(Which is genuinely what it's called. The stuff they make recycled cardboard boxes out of.)

BE

Turns out it was nothing to worry about.

11:58 am
BE

Here's Goldman.

BE

Q16 EBITDA of €323 mn was broadly in line with company consensus/GS
at €319 mn. Divisionally, results were in line with our expectations while
the others line was slightly lower than expected. EBITDA margin expanded
to 15.7%, up 70 bp from 3Q15, despite headwinds from higher raw material
costs and adverse FX. Net debt is €2.95 bn (2.4x EBITDA), down slightly
from 2Q16’s €3.1 bn (2.5x EBITDA). European corrugated volume growth
was in line with the 2% growth seen ytd. Ytd volume growth is 5% while
3Q growth was slightly lower at 3%, driven by fewer working days (c.1%
headwind) and challenging market development, especially in
Argentina/the US. 3Q EPS was €0.56, 6% above consensus but 7% below
our forecast, driven by higher interest cost than we expected.

BE

Analysis
Management expects FY16 EBITDA “in line with market expectations”:
FY16 company consensus is currently at €1,234 mn implying 4Q EBITDA of
€320 mn. Quick win is guided to contribute €33 mn in 2017 and a new
program will be communicated during 2017. Ytd, the cost out program
delivered €49 mn and management is confident it will reach the FY16
target of €75 mn. FX was an €11 mn headwind in the Americas in 3Q and
volume pressure in Argentina and the US was an additional headwind, but
this should ease into 4Q.

11:59 am
BE

Implications
The expanding margin in 3Q and FY16 guided to be in line with market
expectations should provide some relief for the stock which is down 16%
ytd and 3% over the past month (in USD). Implied 4Q EBITDA from
company-compiled consensus of €320 mn looks achievable in our view.
Corrugated box prices were slightly down qoq as the index effect from
lower testliner prices started to feed through, however 3Q box prices were
flat yoy in a constant currency basis. Price increases are currently being
pushed in Argentina and the US as the markets are improving.

BE

And .... either Davy or Goodbody. Wait, I'll toss a coin.

BE

Heads. Goodbody.

12:00 pm
BE

We believe this is a solid performance from Smurfit Kappa with the cash
generation achieved during the period encouraging. We believe this is likely to
continue into Q416 and is a theme to watch in FY17. At current levels the share
price is giving little reward for the company’s sustainable cash generation.

BE

Tails would've been Davy, which would've gone like this.

BE

One of the most attractive characteristics of Smurfit Kappa
Group’s business is its strong cash generation. The company
generated €164m of free cash flow in Q3 and is on-track to
deliver over €320m for the full year, implying a free cash flow
yield of over 7%. The yield increases to over 11% in 2017 as
capex reverts to depreciation. These cash dynamics, combined
with a significant valuation discount to peers, make the current
share price a very attractive investment opportunity. We
reiterate our ‘Outperform’ rating and 3200c price target.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE

That's midday, but there are a few more things.

BE

First, what the actual hell is happening in Benelux?

12:03 pm
BE

PostNL - BPost, of course.

BE

After a hapless feltcollaredsource accidentally emailed details of their merger yesterday.

BE

BPost is "surprised about, and regrets, the inadvertent leakage of an internal and confidential working document leading to press reports about a possible enhanced proposal to PostNL"

12:04 pm
BE

No decisions made yet, but they'll let us know when they are. thumbs up

BE

http://corporate.b...6-11-02?sc_lang=en

BE

PostNL unsurprisingly cheesed by this development.

12:04 pm
BE

"unpleasantly surprised"

BE

And sticking to the knitting. https://www.postnl...ease-of-today.html

BE

Now, people are really willing this to happen this time.

12:06 pm
BE

Jefferies talks us though the logic.

BE

A combination of bpost and PostNL would create Europe’s fourth largest postal operator, with revenues of over €6bn, triple bpost’s parcel revenues to €1.4bn, with market shares of 70% in the Belgian and Dutch B2C parcel segments, in an increasingly competitive and consolidating European parcel market, result in a more balanced profile by segment and unlock PostNL’s dividend streams relatively sooner.

BE

We assume bpost would now have to offer a relatively higher price of €5.50 per PostNL share, implying a premium of close to 30% to the PostNL share price before details of the new offer emerged, compared to an alleged offer price of €5.10 previously, and compared to our stand-alone fair value of €5.00, reflecting expected limited synergies. A takeover offer of €5.50 values PostNL at €2.3bn enterprise value or 7.0x FY17E EV/EBIT, implying a 15% discount to the European postal sector. The discount reflects a relatively challenging Dutch postal market, expected to decline by 8% per annum, and expected pension top-up payments of €350m.

12:07 pm
BE

A takeover of PostNL by bpost for €5.50 per share would be highly
earnings accretive, estimated to add 36% to EPS, reflecting PostNL’s relatively lower
valuation, even when funding 50% of the takeover sum with new equity, requiring a capital
increase of close to 25%, diluting the Belgian's state's interest to 41% . Valuation / risk factors. bpost shares are trading at 7.8x FY17E EV/EBIT, implying a 5% discount to the European postal sector, and offer an above average 5.4% dividend yield. We think relatively defensive yield stocks will continue to perform well in the current low interest rate environment and stick to our Buy rating with a DCF-based €26.5 price target. Key risk factors include faster e-substitution, increasing competition, regulatory measures and acquisition integration risk.

BE

Just Eat, the leading digital marketplace for takeaway food delivery, has issued
an order update for the three months to 30th September 2016. With UK and
total order growth in-line with our expectations, we leave our FY2016 estimates
unchanged and reiterate our Buy recommendation and PT of 734p.
 Total orders +34%. Total orders increased by 34% through 3Q16 year-on-year on both
a reported and LFL basis. This rate of growth is in-line with our expectations and is
respectable given a particularly tough comparative. Note that total orders grew by
+48% on a LFL basis through 3Q15.
 UK orders +28%. Order growth in the UK was softer this quarter which is reflective of
a significantly warmer and dryer summer. Order growth of +28%, however, is in-line
with market expectations. We expect order growth in the UK to accelerate through
the final quarter and are confident that this rate of growth is not the product of
increased competition.
 FY16 guidance increased. Management have increased FY16 revenue and EBITDA
guidance, on a constant exchange rate basis, from £368m/£106m-£108m to
£371m/£109m-£111m. Using current exchange rates though, revised revenue
guidance would increase to £373m while there would be no material change to
underlying EBITDA. We leave our FY2016 estimates unchanged given that we
upgraded our numbers in our previous note ‘Just Getting Going’.
 Trading at a discount to its fundamental worth. Our sum of the parts analysis shows
the fundamental value of the business to be 734p, a c31% premium to the prevailing
market price. This methodology is underpinned by a DCF mode which shows the
shares to be worth 759p.
